net.derquinse.common.collect
Interface Hierarchy<E>

Type Parameters:
E - Type of the elements in the hierarchy.
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractHierarchy, ForwardingHierarchy, ImmutableHierarchy
@Beta
public interface Hierarchy<E>

A hierarchy is a set of objects identified organized in a tree-like structure, where each level is an ordered list. The first level of a hierarchy is the list of elements that have no parent. A hierarchy is rooted if the first level has exactly one element, which is named the root element. Null elements are not allowed. As only an immutable implementation is provided, mutable semantics are not specified yet.

All methods throw NullPointerException if a null value is passed as an argument not marked as nullable.

Author:
Andres Rodriguez
See Also:
Set

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
Returns true if the hierarchy is empty.

int size()
Returns the number of elements in the hierarchy.

containsAll

boolean containsAll(Iterable<? extends E> elements)
Returns true if the hierarchy contains all the provided elements.

elementSet

Set<E> elementSet()
Returns the set of distinct elements contained in this hierarchy.

Returns:
A set containing a live view the elements of the hierarchy.

getFirstLevel

List<E> getFirstLevel()
Returns the first level of the hierarchy. For a rooted hierarchy it will be a single list element.

Returns:
The list of values with no parent. Never null.

isRooted

boolean isRooted()
Returns whether the hierarchy is rooted.

Returns:
True if the first level has one element.

getRoot

E getRoot()
Returns the root element.

Returns:
The only element in the first level.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the hierarchy is not rooted.

getChildren

List<E> getChildren(@Nullable
                    E element)
Returns the children of the specified element.

Parameters:
element - Element which children are requested. If null the first level will be returned.
Returns:
The list of children, the empty list if it has no children. Never null.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified element is not part of the hierarchy.

E getParent(E element)
Returns the parent of the specified element.

Parameters:
element - Element which parent is requested.
Returns:
The parent element or null if it is a first-level element.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified element is not part of the hierarchy.

List<E> getSiblings(E element)
Returns the siblings of the specified element.

Parameters:
element - Element which siblings are requested.
Returns:
The list of siblings. At least with one element, the argument itself.

Returns the index of the specified element among its siblings.

Parameters:
element - Element which index is requested.

Iterable<E> getAncestors(E element)
Returns the ancestors of the specified element.

Parameters:
element - Element which ancestors are requested.
Returns:
The ancestors in descending level order.

IllegalArgumentException - if the specified element is not part of the hierarchy.

getDescendants

Set<E> getDescendants(@Nullable
                      E element)
Returns the descendants of the specified element.

Parameters:
element - Element which descendants are requested. If null the element set is returned.
Returns:
The set of descendants. Iteration order is unspecified.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified element is not part of the hierarchy.

equals

boolean equals(@Nullable
               Object o)
Compares the specified object with this hierarchy for equality. Returns true if the specified object is also a hierarchy, the two hierarchies have the same size, and both contain the same elements in the same coordinates. This definition ensures that the equals method works properly across different implementations of the hierarchy interface.

Overrides:
equals in class Object
Parameters:
o - Object to be compared for equality with this hierarchy.
Returns:
True if the specified object is equal to this hierarchy.

hashCode

int hashCode()
Returns the hash code value for this hierarchy. The hash code of a hierarchy is defined to be the sum of hash(e)^level(e) for every element e of the hierarchy. This definition fulfills the general contract of Object.hashCode().

Overrides:
hashCode in class Object
Returns:
The hash code value for this hierarchy.
See Also:
Object.equals(Object), equals(Object)
